node.text:
The perfect Monday pick-me-up. ✨

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine on August 30, 2021. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
Painstakingly foraged, deconstructed, dried, reconstructed, and mounted, a pressed botanical demands a naturalist’s precision and an artist’s hand. That dualism fits Anne Blackwell Thompson (@blackwell_botanicals) like a pair of waders. Her latest obsession: water lilies, which require changing blotting paper every six hours, day and night, for up to 10 days. Here, Thompson captures the artistic beauty of water lilies in a botanical piece exclusively for Veranda.

Tap the link in bio to learn more about the piece and how you can enter for a chance to win the artwork.
—
Photography by Becky Stayner (@sunnyhousestudio)
Produced by Sara Clark (@saraellisclark)
Written by Tracey Minkin (@tracey_minkin)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in West Village. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
Walking into the upper salon of Emily Eerdmans's West Village gallery-in-residence feels akin to taking a shot of pure caffeine. Both light-filled and lime-lacquered, the immersive space serves as a vivid shop gallery for an ever-changing inventory of antiques and art. Eerdmans (@eerdmansnewyork) softened the salon's electric appearance with gentle details such as tasseled Austrian shades (@samuelandsons), a portiere hiding the kitchen, and monumental Christmas palms. 

Want to see more of this wildly immersive gallery-in-residence? Tap the link in bio!
—
Photography by Kelly Marshall (@sans.murs)
Produced by Dayle Wood (@daylewood24)
Written by Michael Diaz-Griffith (@michaeldiazgriffith)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Positano. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Oh, Italy. You've always been a beauty. ✨
—
📸: @bmseventh
📍: Positano, Italy
#regram

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Montreal, Quebec. May be an image of chandelier, table and indoor.

node.text:
Designer Richard Ouellette and architect Maxime Vandal, the team behind Les Ensembliers (@les_ensembliers), recasted a dilapidated chapel as an art-filled penthouse for former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and his wife, Mila in Montreal. When it came to devising the layout for the 6,000 square feet of living space—plus another 2,000 square feet of rooftop terrace—the challenge, Vandal says, “was to translate the Mulroneys’ life in their previous home to the more contained volume of the apartment without any compromise.”

The goal was to create a residence that is comfortable when it’s just the two of them, while also allowing the couple to host family gatherings and entertain on the generous scale they are accustomed to.

The main entertaining space is divided into three sections including this corner dining area. The majestic antique crystal chandelier anchors the room. A shagreen leather (@garrettleather) covers custom chairs. The painting is by Larry Poons.

To see more of this art-filled penthouse, tap the link in bio.
—
Photography by Thomas Loof (@thomasloof)
Produced by Dayle Wood (@daylewood24)
Written by Stephen Wallis (@stephen_wallis)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Knightsbridge. May be an image of furniture and living room.

node.text:
It was like a scene out of a movie. One day while exploring the quiet London neighborhood of Knightsbridge, an American couple stumbled across a four-story, white stucco rowhouse dripping with charm. The couple couldn't pass up the chance, and not soon after, the home was theirs. 

While stunning from the outside, Boston-based designer Gary McBournie (@garymcbournie) and London-based architect Mike Fisher will tell you that the cinematic appeal disappeared once inside. 

"At one point, you could stand on bare earth, look up through four floors, and see sky,” explains Fisher of Studio Indigo (@studioindigoltd).

The teams looked to historic documents for inspiration to emulate the home's original Victorian elements. However, most of the palette and patterns for the house, for example, came from a single small antique Turkish rug which McBournie had recreated as a large living room rug.  The convivial window seat In the living room overlooks an emerald and white back garden. The striped banquette fabric is by Pierre Frey. The French lantern was found at Carlton Davidson Antiques. 

Tap the link in bio to see more of this storybook rowhouse in London. 
—
Landscape design by Iain MacDonald Design (@iainmacdonald.design)
Photography by Dylan Thomas (@dylan_location)
Written by Celia Barbour

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in San Francisco, California with @thalia_jewelry. May be an image of 1 person and indoor.

node.text:
Jewelry designer Rachel Clinnick-Barbagelata's love for entertaining didn't start with flower arranging or creating beautiful tabletops. It began under the table where she would hide as a child during social get-togethers listening to forks clink and stories of people living in far-off places. 

Nowadays, Clinnick-Barbagelata (@rachelbarbagelata) recreates that magic for her friends and family in her chic Pacific Heights flat. And even when it's just the designer and her family, she still sets a formal table with plenty to eat and countless candles setting the mood for an intimate dinner.

"I think the magic comes from celebrating those little things," says Clinnick-Barbagelata (@thalia_jewelry). "Beautiful aesthetics make me happy and, I believe, elevate everyone’s mood. We linger at the table longer, have discussions...the kids might even stay off their phones."

Tap the link in bio to discover Rachel Clinnick-Barbagelata's timeless entertaining tips.
—
Photography by Nicole Hill Gerulat (@nicolegerulat)
Produced by Rachael Burrow (@rachaelburrow)
Styling by Bianca Sotelo (@afabchallenge)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in New York, New York. May be an image of furniture and living room.

node.text:
“The idea was to make the space feel approachable but artful, using a mix of different eras and aesthetics,” says designer Robert Passal of this Manhattan pied-à-terre. 

His client expressed how they wanted their historic apartment, overlooking Madison Square Park with views of the Flatiron, to feel comfortable and functional. They preserved the 3,200-square-foot residence’s existing layout and retained a good deal of the original millwork and surfaces, but Passal (@robertpassal) added a number of space-redefining touches. He stripped the gray-tone floors and refinished them to showcase more of the wood’s natural graining and color.

Sprinkled around the living room are diverse works of art and objects, from Wedgwood ceramics to ancient sculptures. A pair of 19th-century Italian sconces flanks a still life painting by Alec Soth. The visage clay sculpture is by Pablo Picasso. 

Tap the link in bio to see more of this polished three-bedroom apartment in New York. 
—
Photography by Stephen Kent Johnson (@stephenkentjohnson)
Written by Stephen Wallis (@stephen_wallis)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in New Orleans, Louisiana. May be an image of furniture and bedroom.

node.text:
It's amazing where one can find inspiration. Leontine Linens founder Jane Scott Hodges (@janescotthodges) found it in the British historical drama, "Belgravia," and its namesake neighborhood’s grand Georgian estates appointed with subtle and quiet interiors. 

 “It makes me chuckle, but there’s no denying that the color scheme in these rooms came from that show,” she says of her New Orleans bedroom suite. 

Inspired by the show, Hodges rang Sweet Dupuy of Gibbens Dupuy Decoration (@sweetdupuy) in New Orleans, who arrived at the Hodges’ residence with a single drawer from an 18th-century Italian Rococo polychrome commode. Inside was a large swatch of Pierre Frey’s Mortefontaine fabric (@lamaisonpierrefrey) which quickly became the star of the show. Nearly 30 yards of the historic floral print make up the bed's alcove which resembles English designer Oliver Messel’s famed suite at London’s Dorchester hotel. The Hollywood Regency bed found on Chairish is covered in bedding from Leontine Linens (@leontinelinens). 

Tap the link in bio to see more of this dramatic boudoir. 
—
Photography by Alison Gootee (@alisongootee)
Styling by Suzonne Stirling (@suzonnestirling)
Written by Zoë Gowen (@zoegowen)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Harlem with @savingplaces, and @edgecombeavenue. May be an image of one or more people and outdoors.

node.text:
Let's take a trip back in time to Harlem in 1921.  Men in velvet-collared coats and women in fine frocks buzz outside a stout brick building ready to see a ragtime orchestra in person for the first.  It's opening night at the Renaissance Theatre, the first such venue in New York City built and financed by African Americans, and one of the only theaters of the day that welcomed Black patrons. To say that night of lively music and high-energy dancing was a success is an understatement. 

The Rennie instantly became the social hub of Harlem’s Black community, where creatives, activists, and thought leaders could gather and thrive. Though like many venues, its light began to dim, and the entertainment hall closed in the 1970s. And then, in 2014, Harlem's former cultural epicenter was demolished and replaced with a residential tower. 

In the wake of the Rennie's destruction, Harlem citizens mobilized to prevent other landmarks from suffering similar fates. Grassroots organizations like Save Harlem Now! and While We Are Still Here are working to save a number of Harlem's historic buildings, such as the Apollo Theater and Hotel Theresa, by lobbying for them to be preserved as landmarks. And, these groups are just getting started. 

To learn more about Harlem's next renaissance, tap the link in bio. 

Photographed is Harlem native and scholar Akemi Kochiyama, grand-daughter of Japanese American civil rights activists Bill and Yuri Kochiyama. She lives in a historic brownstone she renovated on the same 126th Street block where her grandparents once lived in public housing. 
—
Photography by Flo Ngala (@flongala)
Written by Shayla Martin (@shayla.martin)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Montreal, Quebec. May be an image of living room.

node.text:
There was a moment early in this complex project overseen by designer Richard Ouellette and architect Maxime Vandal when they turned to each other and thought, "Oh, what have we done?"

The duo, partners of Montreal-based firm Les Ensembliers (@les_ensembliers), had brought their client to view the project which was nothing more than a gutted shell of a former chapel at that moment. While there was a moment of doubt, their client, Mila Mulroney, the wife of former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, knew Ouellette and Vandal were the only ones who could turn the dilapidated space into a graceful, art-filled penthouse. 

The layout and architecture of rooms feel rather traditional, but the couple's lifelong collection of art brings the home to life. In the entry, a treelike sculpture specially commissioned from Canadian artist Laura Santini hangs over elegantly balustraded limestone stairs. The small gallery over the settee highlights other Canadian artists. 

To see more of this art-filled penthouse, tap the link in bio. 
—
Photography by Thomas Loof (@thomasloof)
Produced by Dayle Wood (@daylewood24)
Written by Stephen Wallis (@stephen_wallis)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in West Village. May be an image of furniture and living room.

node.text:
Hidden beneath a 1838 townhouse in Greenwich Village, Emily Eerdmans's art gallery-slash-interiors emporium was once a secret among New York’s design community. That all changed during the early months of the COVID-19 pandemic when the antiques dealer and design historian (@eerdmansnewyork) made the decision to hunker down and transform the unusual space into a gallery-in-residence.

Aubergine lacquer envelopes the private living room while wall-to-wall carpet covers an unrestored parquet floor. A 19th-century French sunburst clock is suspended by a shantung silk bow from Mario Buatta’s living room. The ottoman velvet is by George Spencer through Claremont (@claremontfurnishing). 

Want to see more of this wildly immersive gallery-in-residence? Tap the link in bio!
—
Photography by Kelly Marshall (@sans.murs)
Produced by Dayle Wood (@daylewood24)
Written by Michael Diaz-Griffith (@michaeldiazgriffith)
